186025937.review:
I have conflicting feelings on whether or not I want to recommend this, but overall I think the answer is yes. This is one of the earliest idle games I've ever played, and it's what got me invested in the genre in the first place.

Unfortunately, in that aspect it does show its age; there isn't as much automation/optimization when compared to newer idle games. But it's wonderful to see how far the genre has come over the years, and I think it's worth it to go back in time to where it was in its infancy, if only to see how much we take for granted in new entries.

Obviously, if you don't care for idle games, I'd skip this, especially due to the lack of features prevalent in more recent idle games. But if you're a fan of the genre, give it a go.

185888080.review:
Adventure Capitalist foi divertido quando surgiu há 10 anos, um passatempo viciante que dava uma ideia inicial e superficial sobre acumular riqueza. Era simples: investir, ganhar, reinvestir. Mas, sejamos sinceros, o jogo mostra só o lado glamouroso do capitalismo, sem tocar na parte pesada da exploração de trabalhadores e desigualdade – que é, afinal, o motor real do sistema. No mundo do jogo, todo mundo trabalha feliz e as máquinas fazem milagres, o que está longe de ser a realidade.

Hoje em dia, o jogo sequer abre direito. Talvez seja uma metáfora perfeita: o capitalismo morreu, ou, no mínimo, ficou travado como o servidor desse jogo. Fica aí a reflexão.

185601666.review:
7/10
As someone who’s not typically a fan of idle games, I was hesitant to dive into this one, but I’m glad I gave it a shot. After spending 40 hours to reach 100% completion, I can confidently say it was an enjoyable experience.

The game mechanics are well-designed, and everything worked seamlessly. Progression felt satisfying for the most part, and I appreciated how it managed to keep me engaged despite the slower pace inherent to the idle genre. However, there were moments where the grind felt intentionally excessive --> those "EXTRAAAAA long" sections were a bit of a drag and clearly designed to nudge players toward spending money to speed things up.

That said, I managed to complete the game entirely free 2 play, and it was rewarding to achieve 100% without dropping a dime. For those who enjoy idle games or are curious about trying one, I’d definitely recommend giving this a go. It might surprise you, as it did me.

185595820.review: Start by investing in simple businesses, then reinvest your earnings to expand and dominate various industries. The game is filled with opportunities for growth, from buying upgrades to unlocking new areas. It offers a satisfying progression loop, and the longer you play, the more rewarding it becomes. Perfect for players who love strategy and watching their investments grow while they take a break :))

It's just like other clicker games we know. The only difference is that we can't click in this game like we do in the other idling games. How sad.

There are no value balancing between planets and some events can almost tear apart your soul while trying to achieve the top leader board positions or even getting the last item (that gives a singular boost only exclusive to that event after it ends...)

Instead of making the earth the easiest planet, they implemented some sections that making you wait nearly 30 hours to move on to the next number. The early game plays too fast and late game feels too sluggish.

There are better idling games in the marketplace. Don't even bother playing this sitting and waiting simulator.

185316209.review: 20 dias sem punheta, entrei na farmácia pra comprar um halls, ai a menina do caixa falou assim: "boa noite, posso ajudar?" Mano, quem fala isso?? Todo mundo sabe que as meninas do caixa só falam "Boa noite/Bom dia/Boa tarde" mas pra mim ela falou logo "Boa noite, posso ajudar", safada! ela ta super na minha. Ai eu peguei um halls vermelho e disse: "Quero um halls de morango" ai ela disse: "esse ai é de cereja, o de morango é o mais rosinha" olha que safada, mano, inacreditável, a mina teve a audácia de falar que o halls vermelho não é de morango só pra puxar assunto comigo, decidi ver até a onde a cara-de-pau dela ia, então eu disse "Há... é Tudo a mesma coisa!" então ela deu uma risadinha. Mano não foi uma piada, não tinha motivo pra ela rir! ela riu pra me deixar à vontade e pedir meu zap, tenho certeza. Então fiquei olhando pra cara dela calado por uns 50 segundos pra fazer um elo no flerte porque não era justo só ela fazer tudo, ela perguntando; "Ééé... Deseja mais alguma coisa, senhor??" Olha que safada se oferecendo pra mim no horário de trabalho, então eu só fiquei com o halls na mão olhando para ela, ela começou a olhar pros lados pra ver se alguém tava olhando pra ela pedir meu zap, ela Tava tão eufórica com minha presença que tava começando a suar e encher os olhos de água, certamente imaginando nosso futuro casados. Dois minutos após eu só segurar o halls e olhar nos olhos dela, eu pus a mão no bolso pra pegar a carteira e ela falou: "por favor, não me machuque!" certamente imaginando um sexo selvagem por eu ser esse macho alpha que sou. Então pequei a carteira, abri um sorriso, peguei 2 Reais e paguei o Halls. Ai eu disse "eu voltarei" e uma lágrima desceu pelo rosto dela. Certamente ela está completamente apaixonada por mim e chorando de felicidade.

185144147.review:
[h1]AdVenture Capitalist: 207.2 Hours of Pure Capitalistic Dopamine[/h1]
[i]Dear Diary,
207.2 hours of watching numbers go up, and somehow it's still hypnotic. From Earth to Moon to Mars, I've become the ultimate capitalist overlord, though I wish there were more worlds to conquer.[/i]
[h1]The Capitalism Chronicles[/h1]
[b]Phase 1: The Lemonade Baron[/b]
Started with a humble lemonade stand, ended up running an empire. One click became two, became a thousand, became automated money-printing machines. The dopamine hit of seeing those numbers multiply never gets old, even if my clicking finger begs to differ.
[b]Phase 2: The Interplanetary Tycoon[/b]
Earth wasn't enough, so I conquered the Moon. Moon wasn't enough, so I took Mars. Each planet brought new industries, new strategies, and new ways to watch those sweet, sweet profits roll in. The universe is vast, yet somehow three planets don't feel like enough anymore.
[b]Phase 3: The Angel Investor[/b]
Mastered the art of strategic resets, turning angel investors into my personal army of profit multipliers. Every reset feels like starting fresh but stronger, like a phoenix rising from the ashes of its previous fortune to make an even bigger one.
[h1]The Profit Report[/h1]
Hours invested: 207.2
Planets conquered: All 3 (desperately wanting more)
Angels accumulated: Countless
Lemonade stands owned: More than actual lemons in existence
Profits earned: Numbers too big for calculators
Managers hired: All of them, multiple times
[h1]The Verdict[/h1]
Is it just a number simulator? [b]Yes, and it's beautiful[/b]. Could there be more planets to conquer? [b]Absolutely yes please[/b]. It's like watching your bank account grow, except the numbers are bigger and the IRS can't touch it.
[i]Now, if you'll excuse me, I need to go check if my Mars hotels have generated enough profit to buy another galaxy - oh wait, we can't do that yet. Developers, please note.[/i]
[b]P.S.[/b] - To the developers: Jupiter is right there, just saying.
[h1]Watch My Empire Grow![/h1]
[url=https://www.twitch.tv/profiler93]Profiler93's Capitalist Adventures[/url]

185134937.review:
ผมขอรีวิวแบบเห็นภาพชัดๆนะครับ

ข้อดี
- เป็นเกมแนว idle ที่ปล่อยไว้เดียวเงินไหลเพิ่มขึ้นเอง
- เป็นเกม idle ยุคแรกๆเลยที่ทำออกมาเป็นเกมในโทรศัพท์มาก่อน จนตอนนี้เป็นเกมคอมแล้ว
- เล่นได้นานเพราะมันมีให้คุณเล่นถึง 3 โลก
- ของที่แจกตามกิจกรรมต่างๆแจกค่อนข้างดี

ข้อเสีย
- ด้วยความที่เป็นเกม idle มันจะมีช่วงที่เติบโตไว และเติบโตช้า ซึ่งช่วงหลังๆของเกมในแต่ละโลกมันกินเวลานานมาก คือผมนั่งรีเอานางฟ้านั่งเล่นอีกเกือบอาทิตย์นึง แต่ได้อัพเกรดเพิ่มแค่ 1 ขั้นจากที่เหลืออีก 10-15 ขั้น
- ระบบการคูณรายได้ที่เติมเงินหรือใช้ทอง (cash) ในเกมซื้อมันใช้ได้แค่โลกต่อโลกนั้นๆ ถ้าอยากเล่นไปไวๆการซื้อช่วยได่ ได้เยอะเลยด้วย แต่เปลืองเงินมากๆ
- ระบบชุด ตอนแรกผมนึกว่ามันซื้อมาละช่วยเยอะเก่งเลยงี้ ไม่ใช่นะครับ ซื้อมา มีเลเวล มันอัพได้ด้วยเห้ย! หมายความว่าเกมมันพร้อมดูดเงินในกระเป๋าเงินคุณหนักอยู่
- ระบบดาวดวงอื่นที่ใส่มาในเกม content มันเหมือนกันครับ แต่ความเร็วในการหาเงิน กับการใช้เงินในการอัพเกรดมันก้าวกระโดดไปเยอะ ทำให้ใช้เวลาเยอะกว่าเดิมในการเล่นให้จบครับ
- ถึงจะบอกว่าต่อให้ปิดเกมไปแล้วเงินมันก็ไหลขึ้นไปเอง แต่ผมแอบรู้สึกว่าจำนวนเงินที่ได้มันไม่ตรงกับตอนเปิดทิ้งไว้
- เกมนี้กินสเปค cpu สูงมาก ทั้งๆที่เกมมันก็มีแค่ตัวเลขขยับอะ
- กิจกรรมของแจกดีใช่ครับ แต่แจกของเลเวล 1 ไหนจะกว่าจะเล่นให้ได้อันดับดีๆเสียเวลาเยอะมากอีกทั้งถ้าคุณอยากติดอันดับดีๆคุณจำเป็นที่จะต้องเติมเงินเพื่อทำให้คุณติดอันดับ + กิจกรรมนึงจบไม่ถึงวันกิจกรรมใหม่มา
- ข้อนี้อาจจะเป็นแค่ผมคือพวกเกมแนว idle มันจะอยากทำให้เรากลับมาเล่นมันตลอด ทำให้ผมเสียสมาธิในชีวิตผมไปช่วงนึงเพราะอยากกลับมากดเกมนี้ต่อ แต่พอเข้าเกมมาอัพไรไม่ได้รีวนซ้ำรอบนึง อัพเต็ม ปิดเกม ละวนลูปเดิม
- ถ้าคุณอยากเก็บ Achievement ให้ครบแบบ 100% ผมว่ามีเกินปีนึง ซึ่งอาจจะเกินด้วยครับถ้าเป็นสายฟรีนะ

184677753.review:
Adventure Capitalist is an engaging and laid-back idle game that's perfect for players looking for a relaxing yet strategic experience. I've been playing for a few hours, and it strikes a great balance between simplicity and depth. The game focuses on building a capitalist empire by managing investments and unlocking upgrades to increase profits exponentially.

What makes it stand out is its incremental gameplay, where you can step away and still make progress, which is ideal for casual gamers or those who enjoy multitasking. It's not overly intense, so you can enjoy it at your own pace while planning your next moves to maximize earnings.

If you're a fan of idle games or just want something to pass the time without a heavy commitment, I'd recommend giving Adventure Capitalist a try. The strategic element of deciding where to allocate resources keeps it interesting, and the whimsical humor adds to the charm.Adventure Capitalist is a relaxing idle game that offers a perfect mix of simplicity and strategy. In the game, you build a capitalist empire by managing investments and unlocking upgrades to boost profits.

One of its standout features is the incremental gameplay, allowing you to progress even when you're not actively playing, making it ideal for casual gamers. It offers a laid-back experience while still encouraging strategic thinking to maximize earnings.

If you enjoy idle games or want something light and entertaining, I recommend trying Adventure Capitalist. Its strategic resource allocation and whimsical humor enhance the overall charm.

184420459.review:
This game serves as a stark reminder of the inherent contradictions within systems of wealth accumulation, particularly capitalism. On one hand, we see the concentration of wealth, and on the other, we witness the accumulation of misery and suffering for those who produce that wealth. The game presents this complex idea in a way that challenges the player’s perspective, forcing them to confront the deep inequalities built into economic systems.

While the gameplay itself can be engaging, it also makes you reflect on the broader implications of wealth distribution and class struggle. The contrast between the luxurious lives of the wealthy and the brutal toil of the working class is presented with brutal clarity, almost mirroring the antagonistic nature of capitalist accumulation. This isn’t just a game, but a critical commentary on the real-world consequences of these systems.

However, the game could benefit from a more nuanced exploration of these ideas, as some of the political and economic concepts presented here may feel a bit overwhelming for those not familiar with them. Still, if you’re up for a challenging, thought-provoking experience that critiques capitalism’s inherent contradictions, this game is worth a look.

184259554.review:
Adventure Capitalist: A Comprehensive Review

Introduction:
Released by Hyper Hippo in 2014, Adventure Capitalist is a popular idle clicker game available on iOS, Android, and Steam. The objective is simple: become the world’s richest capitalist by investing in businesses, collecting profits, and expanding your empire. The game’s addictive nature and incremental progression make it a standout in the idle clicker genre.

Gameplay Mechanics:
At its core, Adventure Capitalist revolves around tapping the screen to earn money (coins). Early on, earnings are minimal, but as you unlock businesses like lemonade stands, oil rigs, and space exploration, profits increase exponentially.

- Businesses and Investments: Players begin with basic businesses, and as progress is made, they can invest in more lucrative ventures. Each business generates profits that can be boosted by upgrades and managers.

- Managers: Hiring managers automates business operations, allowing passive income while you focus on expanding your empire. This makes the game less reliant on constant tapping, perfect for those who prefer idle play.

- Upgrades and Boosts: Each business has its own set of upgrades, allowing you to increase profits. Temporary boosts enhance your earnings, and upgrades become crucial for achieving rapid progress.

- Prestige System: The prestige mechanic rewards players who reset their progress by earning angel investors, providing a permanent bonus to profits. This adds depth and replayability, making resets an integral part of long-term progression.

- Time Management: Adventure Capitalist thrives on balancing active play and idle periods. The game generates money even when you’re away, and checking in periodically ensures consistent growth. 

Monetization:
Adventure Capitalist is free-to-play but offers in-app purchases of Mega Bucks, the premium currency. Mega Bucks allow players to buy boosts, skip wait times, or restart businesses. While optional, these purchases speed up progression and make the game more convenient.

The monetization is balanced enough to allow enjoyment without spending money, though players can accelerate their experience with real-world purchases.

Visuals and Audio:
The graphics are simple yet effective, with a cartoonish aesthetic. The business icons are easy to recognize, and later, space-themed businesses add vibrant visuals. 

The audio features light, upbeat tunes that complement the game's idle mechanics. Though not groundbreaking, it provides a pleasant background.

User Experience:
The user interface is intuitive, and the tutorial is smooth, making the game accessible to new players. The layout is clean, making it easy to understand businesses, managers, upgrades, and boosts. Regular event notifications offer limited-time bonuses, giving extra incentive for players to return.

The prestige system and milestones offer a rewarding sense of progression. Despite the repetitive nature, these long-term goals keep the game exciting.

Strengths:
1. Addictive Gameplay Loop: The satisfying cycle of earning, upgrading, and resetting keeps players engaged. Progress feels rewarding as businesses grow and profits snowball.

2. Engaging Prestige System: The prestige mechanic provides long-term progression, allowing players to reset their progress in exchange for permanent boosts.

3. Idle Play Option: The idle system means that players can enjoy the game without constant active participation, making it ideal for casual play.

4. Free-to-Play: While in-app purchases are available, the game remains entirely playable without spending money. Players can progress at their own pace.

Weaknesses:
1. Repetitive Gameplay: The game’s loop can feel monotonous over time. Constantly upgrading businesses and resetting progress may lack variety for some players.

2. Emphasis on Microtransactions: Though not necessary to enjoy the game, Mega Bucks can be tempting, offering speed boosts that may feel like an added pressure to spend.

3. Limited Social Features: While there are occasional events, the game lacks extensive multiplayer options. The social aspect is mainly restricted to leaderboards and competitions.

Conclusion:
Adventure Capitalist is an enjoyable and rewarding idle clicker game. Its core loop of earning, upgrading, and resetting provides hours of entertainment. While the repetitive nature can be a drawback, the prestige system and the idle mechanics keep the experience engaging. The game’s free-to-play model ensures accessibility for casual players, and while microtransactions are present, they are not essential. If you enjoy idle games or incremental progression, Adventure Capitalist delivers a fun and satisfying experience.

183775497.review:
Steam Review for AdVenture Capitalist
(Over 900 Hours Played)

Recommended: ✅
Hours Played: 900+
Overall Rating: 9/10

If you’ve ever dreamed of becoming the ultimate tycoon, turning a lemonade stand into a galactic empire, and watching numbers climb higher than your expectations, then AdVenture Capitalist is the perfect game for you. After spending over 900 hours playing, I can confidently say this game delivers a highly addictive and satisfying experience for fans of idle and incremental games.

The Gameplay Loop
At its core, AdVenture Capitalist is simple yet endlessly rewarding. Start small with a lemonade stand, upgrade it, and eventually automate it with a manager. Before you know it, you’re investing in oil companies, movie studios, and eventually, colonizing the Moon and Mars.

The addictive nature lies in its progression system. There’s always something to upgrade, optimize, or unlock. The game’s clever inclusion of Angel Investors encourages restarting your empire to gain exponential boosts, giving that sweet sense of progress every single time.

Even after 900+ hours, there’s always a goal on the horizon, whether it’s completing the Earth empire, maxing out Lunar businesses, or diving into limited-time events for unique rewards. It’s easy to step away and come back days later, only to find massive gains waiting for you.

What Keeps You Playing?
The core appeal of AdVenture Capitalist is that it respects your time. It’s an idle game, so the bulk of its magic happens in the background. Whether you’re playing actively or leaving it running while you do something else, you’re always progressing. The game never feels like it punishes you for taking breaks.

What sets this game apart is its humor and charm. The ridiculous business descriptions, quirky managers, and over-the-top take on capitalism are a joy to experience. The special events also add variety, giving players new ways to engage and earn exclusive items.

Pros:
Highly satisfying progression system
Addictive idle mechanics that work even when offline
Quirky humor and playful take on capitalism
Frequent special events keep things fresh
Free-to-play without being pay-to-win (microtransactions are optional but not necessary)
Cons:
Can get repetitive after extended sessions
Long-term players may wish for more late-game content
Limited interaction in later stages, as the game becomes mostly automated
Final Thoughts
I never thought I’d spend over 900 hours clicking buttons and watching numbers go up, but here I am, still loving every second of it. AdVenture Capitalist isn’t a game for everyone, but for fans of idle games or those who enjoy watching progress unfold at an absurd scale, it’s a perfect fit.

If you’re looking for a casual, low-maintenance game to check on while multitasking, or a relaxing time sink that’s oddly satisfying, AdVenture Capitalist is an absolute gem. It’s more than just a game; it’s a lighthearted ode to the absurdity of capitalism that’ll keep you coming back for more.

Final Rating: 9/10
“You can always make more money... but more importantly, you can always make more fun!”

Hours Played Breakdown:

Active Gameplay: ~300 Hours
Idle/Away Time: ~600 Hours
(What can I say? Even my breaks are productive in AdCap!)

183768226.review:
The epitome of idle games. It’s the game people had on their phones just to pass the time and I can’t really say it’s different now. A few updates and events have been added throughout its lifetime that add microtransactions as everything nowadays but mostly just a timewaster. It of course has some strategy when it comes to the fastest way to complete it but nothing more than some simple resource management and math. All consisting of 4-5 screens worth of content where you upgrade and buy shops to make the number bigger. Truly a bigger number better type of game with a simple art direction and interactivity.

While there are microtransactions they’re not needed to finish the game within a reasonable timespan in terms of hours played. Scoring well on a weekly challenge leaderboard once basically sets you up with the same amount as a few dollars worth. Though speaking of weekly challenges, they were fun exactly once as the time commitment is insane for what you get without really being that interesting.

Achievement catalogue is mostly just progression and funny number of x amount of things. For what it is while being free I can’t really complain and it seems like the dev at least enjoyed creating something back in the day. Get it if you want to waste some hours but not for entertainment which is why I won't recommend it., my rough guess would be about 30h of gameplay if you optimize and utilize your offline time well.
